title: Nicole Beck
text:
Nicole Elise Beck (born 28 May 1988) is a female Australian <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who plays as a <a href="wing%20%28rugby%20union%29">wing</a> for <a href="Australia%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a>, <a href="Sydney%20Rugby%20Union">Sydney</a> and <a href="Sydney%20University%20Football%20Club">Sydney University</a>. She won a gold medal at the <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a> in Rio.
Life.
A former Australian <a href="Touch%20football%20%28rugby%20league%29">touch football</a> representative, Beck was selected by <a href="Australia%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Wallaroos</a> coach <a href="Steve%20Hamson">Steve Hamson</a> after just two games of 15-a-side rugby and made her international debut in the test match lost 36–3 to the <a href="New%20Zealand%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Black Ferns</a> on 14 October 2008 at <a href="Viking%20Park">Viking Park</a> in <a href="Canberra">Canberra</a>. Only a few months before, Beck had been chosen to play with Australia Women's Sevens for the <a href="2009%20Rugby%20World%20Cup%20Sevens">2009 World Cup</a> qualifiers scheduled on 25–26 July 2008 at <a href="Apia%20Park">Apia Park</a> in <a href="Samoa">Samoa</a>. She scored a decisive try on full-time in the 22–15 win against New Zealand, claiming the Oceania Sevens champions title.
The following year, Australia won the <a href="2009%20Rugby%20World%20Cup%20Sevens">Rugby World Cup Sevens</a> defeating 15-10 New Zealand in a final started with a try by Beck in the second minute and ended in <a href="extra-time">extra-time</a> with a golden point strike by <a href="Shelly%20Matcham">Shelly Matcham</a>.
Beck played an important role in Australia's third place at the <a href="2010%20Women%27s%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2010 Women's Rugby World Cup</a>, scoring 1 try, 11 conversions and 1 penalty, becoming one of the nominees for the <a href="IRB%20Awards%232010">2010 IRB Women's Personality of the Year</a> and pulling off a great try-saving tackle on <a href="Fiona%20Pocock">Fiona Pocock</a> during the semi-final against <a href="England%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>. She was a member of <a href="Australia%20women%27s%20national%20rugby%20sevens%20team">Australia's</a> team at the <a href="Rugby%20sevens%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20tournament">2016 Olympics</a>, defeating <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a> in the final to win the inaugural Olympic gold medal in the sport.
Beck currently studies a Bachelor of Educational Studies at <a href="Charles%20Sturt%20University">Charles Sturt University</a>.
At the <a href="2017%20Australia%20Day%20Honours">2017 Australia Day Honours</a> she received the <a href="Order%20of%20Australia">Medal of the Order of Australia</a> for service to sport as a gold medallist at the Rio 2016 Olympic Games.
